title: 112_hr2867
content:
The Act is titled the "United States Commission on International Religious Freedom Reform and Reauthorization Act of 2011." It establishes that each member of the Commission shall serve a 2-year term and may not serve more than 2 terms. The Act limits members of the United States Commission on International Religious Freedom to serving a maximum of 2 terms. If a member attends less than 75% of meetings during a term, they are ineligible for reappointment. The Act restricts members of the US Commission on International Religious Freedom to two terms. If a member attends less than 75% of meetings during a term, they cannot be reappointed. Additionally, members are not eligible to serve as Chair for a second consecutive term. Members are also subject to federal travel regulations. Members of the US Commission on International Religious Freedom are subject to federal travel regulations and must adhere to antidiscrimination laws. SEC. 3. APPLICATION OF ANTIDISCRIMINATION LAWS.
    Section 204 of the International Religious Freedom Act of 1998 is amended to include protections against employment discrimination, fair labor standards, employee polygraph protection, veterans' employment rights, and other employee rights for those whose pay is disbursed by the Secretary of the Senate. The Commission shall be treated as an employing office of the Senate or the House of Representatives, and pending claims can be maintained under the International Religious Freedom Act of 1998. Authorization of appropriations is also included. SEC. 4. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2012 through 2014. SEC. 5. Amendments to standards of conduct and disclosure. SEC. 6. Termination. SEC. 5 of the International Religious Freedom Act of 1998 is amended to increase the financial disclosure threshold and change the department name. SEC. 6 is also amended to extend the termination date. SEC. 7 requires a report on the effectiveness of the Act within a year of enactment. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report on the implementation of the Act and its amendments within a year of enactment. The report will review the effectiveness of US Government programs promoting international religious freedom and assess the Office on International Religious Freedom's roles and functions. The report will assess government programs promoting international religious freedom, including the roles of the Office on International Religious Freedom and the Ambassador at Large. It will also review the goals of the United States Commission on International Religious Freedom. The report will review the International Religious Freedom Act of 1998, the structure of the United States Commission on International Religious Freedom, and the relationship between the Ambassador at Large for International Religious Freedom and the Commission, with a focus on possible reforms to improve their effectiveness.
